title: Missing HTTP status code on tombstone HTML/Turtle responses
description:
In serveEventTombstone, servePlaceTombstone, and serveOrganizationTombstone (internal/api/handlers/public_pages.go:244-341), when serving HTML or Turtle formats, the code doesn't set the HTTP status to 410 Gone. Only JSON-LD tombstones correctly return 410. HTML/Turtle return 200 OK, which violates HTTP semantics for deleted resources.

Impact: Incorrect HTTP semantics, search engines may not properly handle deleted resources
Location: internal/api/handlers/public_pages.go:266-274, 299-307, 332-340
Suggested fix: Add w.WriteHeader(http.StatusGone) before writing HTML/Turtle tombstone responses
close_reason: Fixed tombstone status code bug: HTML and Turtle tombstone responses now correctly return 410 Gone status. Added serveHTMLWithStatus() and serveTurtleWithStatus() helper methods to allow specifying status codes. Also fixed root cause: PublicPagesHandler now checks if entities are soft-deleted (via Lifecycle field) and serves tombstones appropriately. Added comprehensive integration tests to verify all three content types (JSON-LD, HTML, Turtle) return 410 Gone for deleted resources.

title: High: Tombstone feed not integrated with change feed
description:
Files: internal/api/handlers/feeds.go, tests/integration/feeds_tombstone_test.go

Test failures show tombstones aren't appearing in change feed:
TestFeedsTombstoneOrdering/tombstones_have_monotonic_sequence_numbers FAILED
Expected 3 tombstone events, got 0

Root cause:
- Change feed queries event_changes table
- Tombstones stored in event_tombstones table
- No JOIN or UNION between these tables

Impact:
- Federation peers don't receive delete notifications
- Breaks SEL synchronization protocol
- Violates FR-030 (delete propagation)

Fix: Modify ListEventChanges query to include tombstones with action='delete' or create separate tombstone feed endpoint.

Reference: Phase 8 US6 T100, T107
close_reason: Created migration 000011 with database trigger to automatically create event_changes records when tombstones are created. The trigger function inserts a record with action='delete', changed_fields containing deletion metadata, and snapshot containing the tombstone payload. This ensures federation peers receive delete notifications through the change feed.

title: Enhance federation sync to extract nested place/organization entities
description:
**Context**: Federation sync endpoint (/api/v1/federation/sync) currently only processes scalar event fields. It doesn't extract or create nested location and organizer entities from JSON-LD payloads.

**Test failing**: TestFederationSyncURIPreservation/places_and_organizations_also_preserve_URIs

**What's needed**:
1. In internal/domain/federation/sync.go, enhance mapJSONLDToEvent() to:
   - Extract 'location' object from JSON-LD payload
   - Extract 'organizer' object from JSON-LD payload
   - Extract @id from each as federation_uri
2. Call UpsertPlace/UpsertOrganization with federation URIs (reference implementation in internal/domain/events/ingest.go lines 150-192)
3. Wire up place_id/organizer_id to event params

**Files involved**:
- internal/domain/federation/sync.go (line 426+, mapJSONLDToEvent function)
- internal/domain/events/ingest.go (has reference implementation)
- tests/integration/federation_sync_uri_preservation_test.go (line 136-168)

**Impact**: Low priority (P3) - test is for edge case, main federation sync works. This is a nice-to-have feature for complete federation support.
close_reason:
Implemented nested entity extraction for federation sync. Federation sync now properly extracts and upserts location (Place) and organizer (Organization) entities from JSON-LD event payloads, preserving their federation URIs.

IMPLEMENTATION:
✅ Added EntityCreateFields struct for DRY code reuse
✅ Added FederationURI to PlaceCreateParams and OrganizationCreateParams
✅ Implemented extractPlaceFromPayload() and extractOrganizationFromPayload() helpers
✅ Enhanced SyncEvent to upsert entities before upserting events
✅ Added conditional ON CONFLICT logic (federation_uri vs ulid)
✅ Updated both SyncRepository and EventRepository implementations

TEST RESULTS:
✅ All 92 integration tests passing (100% pass rate)
✅ TestFederationSyncURIPreservation/places_and_organizations_also_preserve_URIs ✅

COMMIT: 56be4ba - feat(federation): extract and upsert nested place/organization entities

title: Replace magic numbers with named constants
description:
Purpose: improve maintainability by replacing hard-coded limits/defaults with named constants in domain/API/storage where appropriate.

Scope:
- Focus on limits/defaults/timeouts in production code (exclude test data, Go time layout strings like '2006-01-02', and protocol URLs).

Candidate locations (examples; adjust if better candidates found):
- internal/domain/federation/changefeed.go (default limit 50, max limit 200, limit+1)
- internal/api/handlers/feeds.go (limit 1..200)
- internal/storage/postgres/events_repository.go (default limit 50, limit+1)
- internal/api/router.go (5s timeout, loop count 10)

Guidance:
- Prefer package-level constants close to usage.
- Reuse existing constants in internal/domain/federation/constants.go when applicable.
- Avoid a monolithic repo-wide constants file unless a value is shared across packages (if shared, create a small shared constants package or move to config).

Acceptance criteria:
- Constants added/refactored and references updated.
- No behavior change.
- Docs updated if needed.
- Tests still pass.

Note: align with specs/001-sel-backend/spec.md or plan/SEL_Implementation_Plan.md as implementation hygiene.
close_reason: Replaced magic numbers with named constants across federation, events, and API packages. Created 6 new constants, updated 9 usages. All tests pass.

title: Fix confidence value conversion in provenance repository - potential data corruption
description: CONFIRMED CRITICAL: Schema stores confidence as DECIMAL(3,2) with CHECK (confidence BETWEEN 0 AND 1). Code at lines 136-137, 212, 269, 293 divides by 100.0, turning 0.95 into 0.0095. FIX: Remove '/100.0' division. Also verify pgtype.Numeric access pattern - may need row.Confidence.Float64 instead of .Int.Int64(). Affects ALL API responses with provenance data.
close_reason: Fixed confidence conversion from pgtype.Numeric. Removed incorrect /100.0 division that was corrupting values (0.95 → 0.0095). Now uses Float64Value().Float64 for correct DECIMAL(3,2) extraction. Fixed in 4 locations: GetEventSources (line 135-140), GetCanonicalFieldValue (line 207-217), mapFieldProvenanceRows (line 273-283), mapFieldProvenanceRowsFromPaths (line 305-315).

title: Add monitoring and alerting for idempotency cleanup job
description:
Implement monitoring, metrics, and alerting for the IdempotencyCleanupWorker background job.

**Background**:
- IdempotencyCleanupWorker added in server-brb (P2 security fix)
- Deletes expired idempotency keys (>24h old) via River job queue
- Currently runs with no visibility into success/failure or cleanup metrics

**Requirements**:
1. **Metrics** (Prometheus-compatible):
   - idempotency_keys_deleted_total (counter)
   - idempotency_keys_cleanup_duration_seconds (histogram)
   - idempotency_keys_cleanup_errors_total (counter)
   - idempotency_keys_table_size (gauge, optional)

2. **Logging**:
   - Log cleanup job start/completion with row count
   - Log errors with context (query failure, connection issues)
   - Use structured logging (depends on server-3yq)

3. **Health Checks**:
   - Expose cleanup job status in /readyz endpoint
   - Flag unhealthy if cleanup hasn't run in >48h
   - Flag unhealthy if last 3 runs failed

4. **Alerting** (recommended thresholds):
   - Alert if cleanup job fails 3 times consecutively
   - Alert if table size exceeds expected growth (>10K keys/day)
   - Alert if cleanup duration >30s (potential performance issue)

**Implementation**:
1. Update internal/jobs/workers.go:
   - Add metrics collection to IdempotencyCleanupWorker.Work()
   - Log cleanup results with structured logging
   - Report errors to River's error handler

2. Create internal/metrics/cleanup.go:
   - Define Prometheus metrics for cleanup job
   - Register metrics with global registry

3. Update internal/api/handlers/health.go:
   - Add cleanup job health check to /readyz
   - Query River job status table for last run time/status

4. Document monitoring setup in docs/OPERATIONS.md (new file)

**Files to Modify**:
- internal/jobs/workers.go (IdempotencyCleanupWorker)
- internal/api/handlers/health.go (/readyz endpoint)
- internal/metrics/ (new package)

**Testing**:
- Unit test cleanup job with mocked metrics collector
- Integration test: run cleanup, verify metrics emitted
- Manual test: trigger cleanup, check /readyz reflects status

**Success Criteria**:
- Cleanup job emits metrics on every run
- /readyz fails if cleanup unhealthy
- Operators can set up alerts based on exposed metrics
- Documentation includes example Prometheus/Grafana configs

**References**:
- River job monitoring: https://riverqueue.com/docs/monitoring
- Prometheus Go client: https://github.com/prometheus/client_golang

title: Low: Cursor encoding not URL-safe for all consumers
description:
File: internal/api/pagination/cursor.go:22-24, 51-53

Uses base64.RawURLEncoding which is URL-safe but some clients may expect standard base64 or have issues with the format.

Current implementation:
- EncodeEventCursor: base64.RawURLEncoding (no padding)
- EncodeChangeCursor: base64.RawURLEncoding (no padding)

Considerations:
- RawURLEncoding is correct for URLs
- No padding is cleaner
- Standard is well-established

Not a bug, but worth documenting the choice and adding examples in API docs.

Fix: Add cursor format documentation to OpenAPI spec and quickstart.md with encoding examples.

Reference: Phase 8 US6, FR-006 pagination requirements
close_reason: Added comprehensive cursor documentation to godoc, OpenAPI spec, and quickstart guide. Documented base64.RawURLEncoding choice and emphasized treating cursors as opaque strings.

title: Security Enhancement: Consider adding timing attack protection for login
description:
**Current State**: Login handler uses bcrypt.CompareHashAndPassword which has constant-time properties for password comparison, but the overall login flow may still leak timing information:
- User lookup (`GetUserByUsername`) may have different timing based on database state
- Early returns for user-not-found vs invalid-password may leak information

**Security Impact**: LOW
- Sophisticated attacker could potentially enumerate valid usernames via timing analysis
- Rate limiting (5 attempts per 15 min) mitigates brute force attacks

**Recommendation** (Optional Enhancement):
1. Add artificial delay to normalize response times
2. Consider using constant-time comparison for username lookup results
3. Ensure identical code paths for user-not-found and invalid-password cases

**Priority**: P3 (nice-to-have, rate limiting already provides good protection)

title: Implement structured logging with zerolog
description:
Replace ad-hoc logging with structured logging using zerolog library.

**Current State**:
- Basic logger created in config/config.go
- Inconsistent logging patterns across codebase
- No correlation IDs or request tracing
- Limited observability for debugging production issues

**Requirements**:
- Consistent structured logging across all packages
- Request correlation IDs (X-Request-ID header)
- Contextual logging with key-value pairs

title: Medium: Missing transaction boundaries in federation sync
description:
File: internal/domain/federation/sync.go:102-162

SyncEvent performs multiple database operations without transaction:
1. GetEventByFederationURI
2. GetFederationNodeByDomain
3. UpsertFederatedEvent

If step 3 fails, event may be partially synced or federation node state inconsistent.

No transaction = no atomicity:
- Can't rollback on validation failure
- Race condition if two syncs for same URI arrive
- Orphaned data on failure

Impact:
- Data integrity issues
- Cannot guarantee all-or-nothing semantics
- Race conditions in concurrent sync

Fix: Wrap entire SyncEvent in database transaction:
tx, err := db.Begin(ctx)
defer tx.Rollback()
// ... all operations
tx.Commit()

Reference: AGENTS.md database guidelines, data integrity requirements
close_reason: Added transaction support to federation sync operations. SyncRepository now supports WithTransaction() method that wraps all database operations (GetEventByFederationURI, GetFederationNodeByDomain, UpsertFederatedEvent, CreateOccurrence) in atomic transaction. Automatic rollback on errors, commit on success. Data integrity guaranteed. All tests passing.

title: Medium: Missing rate limit differentiation for federation endpoints
description:
Files: internal/api/router.go, internal/api/middleware/ratelimit.go

Federation sync endpoint (/api/v1/federation/sync) uses same rate limits as public endpoints, but should have federation-specific tier.

Current tiers (from FR-025):
- Public: 60/min
- Agent: 300/min  
- Admin: 1000/min

Missing: Federation tier (suggested: 500/min, configurable per node)

Impact:
- High-volume federation partners get throttled incorrectly
- No per-node rate limit configuration
- Cannot prioritize trusted vs untrusted nodes

Fix: Add federation rate limit tier with per-node configuration stored in federation_nodes.rate_limit_override.

Reference: Phase 8 US6, SEL Interoperability Profile
close_reason: Added TierFederation rate limit tier (500 req/min default, configurable via RATE_LIMIT_FEDERATION env var). Federation sync endpoint now uses dedicated tier instead of agent tier. Prevents high-volume federation partners from being throttled incorrectly. SEL Interoperability Profile requirement satisfied.

title: Security: Add security headers middleware
description:
**Issue**: No security headers middleware found. Missing critical security headers:
- `X-Frame-Options` (clickjacking protection)
- `X-Content-Type-Options` (MIME sniffing protection)
- `Strict-Transport-Security` (HSTS for HTTPS enforcement)
- `Content-Security-Policy` (XSS protection)
- `X-XSS-Protection` (legacy XSS filter)

**Security Impact**:
- Vulnerable to clickjacking attacks (iframe embedding)
- MIME confusion attacks possible
- No HSTS preload (allows downgrade attacks)
- Missing defense-in-depth against XSS

**Recommendation**:
1. Create `internal/api/middleware/security_headers.go`
2. Add headers:
   - `X-Frame-Options: DENY`
   - `X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff`
   - `Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains` (production only)
   - `Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'` (adjust for admin UI)
   - `X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block`
3. Apply to router middleware stack

**Priority**: P1 (missing standard web security headers)
notes:
**Implementation Complete** ✅

Created `internal/api/middleware/security_headers.go` with headers:
- X-Frame-Options: DENY (clickjacking protection)
- X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff (MIME sniffing protection)  
- X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block (legacy XSS filter)
- Referrer-Policy: strict-origin-when-cross-origin (privacy)
- Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; script-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline' (XSS defense)
- Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains; preload (HSTS, production + HTTPS only)

**Tests**: 5 tests added in security_headers_test.go, all passing
**Applied**: Router middleware chain updated (first in chain to ensure headers on all responses)
close_reason: Implemented and tested CORS + security headers middleware. All tests passing (10 new tests added).

title: High: Missing context cancellation checks in sync operations
description:
Files: internal/domain/federation/sync.go, internal/domain/federation/changefeed.go

Federation sync and change feed services don't check for context cancellation (ctx.Done()) during potentially long-running operations. This can lead to:
- Wasted resources when client disconnects
- Database queries continuing after request timeout
- No graceful shutdown capability

Missing checks in:
- SyncService.SyncEvent (lines 102-162)
- ChangeFeedService.GetChanges (lines 91-192)

Fix: Add context checks at key points:
if ctx.Err() != nil {
    return nil, ctx.Err()
}

Reference: Phase 8 US6, SEL Interoperability Profile requirement
close_reason: Added context cancellation checks to federation sync and change feed services: 1) SyncEvent checks context at start, before database operations, and before upsert 2) GetChanges checks context at start, before database query, and before processing results. This ensures graceful handling of client disconnects, request timeouts, and server shutdowns.

title: Security: Add CORS configuration
description:
**Issue**: No CORS middleware or configuration found in the codebase.

**Security Impact**: Without CORS configuration:
- Browser-based clients cannot make cross-origin requests to the API
- Federation sync from browser contexts may be blocked
- Admin UI (if served from different origin) cannot access API

**Recommendation**:
1. Add CORS middleware in `internal/api/middleware/cors.go`
2. Configure allowed origins based on environment:
   - Development: Allow localhost origins
   - Production: Whitelist specific trusted origins
3. Set appropriate headers:
   - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`
   - `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`
   - `Access-Control-Allow-Headers`
   - `Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true` (for cookie-based auth)
4. Apply to router in `internal/api/router.go`

**Priority**: P1 (blocks cross-origin API access)
notes:
**Implementation Complete** ✅

Created `internal/api/middleware/cors.go` with:
- Development mode: allows all origins
- Production mode: requires CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS env var (comma-separated whitelist)
- Handles preflight OPTIONS requests (204 No Content)
- Sets appropriate headers: Allow-Origin, Allow-Credentials, Allow-Methods, Allow-Headers, Max-Age

**Configuration**:
- Added CORSConfig to config package
- Auto-configured based on ENVIRONMENT
- Documented in .env.example

title: Medium: No idempotency protection for federation sync endpoint
description:
Files: internal/api/handlers/federation.go:154-214, internal/domain/federation/sync.go

The federation sync endpoint lacks idempotency protection. Multiple syncs of same event with same data cause:
- Redundant database writes
- Version number increments on no-op updates
- Wasted resources

Current flow:
1. Receive payload
2. Check if event exists by federation_uri
3. UPSERT (always writes)

Missing:
- Idempotency-Key header support (FR-014)
- Content hash comparison to detect no-op updates
- Deduplication for rapid retries

Impact:
- Unnecessary database writes
- Version inflation
- Cannot deduplicate retries

Fix: 
1. Add Idempotency-Key middleware to /federation/sync route
2. Compare content hash before upsert
3. Return 200 (not 201) if content unchanged

Reference: Phase 8 US6 T103, FR-014 idempotency requirement
close_reason: Implemented idempotency protection for federation sync endpoint. Added payload hash comparison, Idempotency-Key header support, and duplicate request handling. Tests passing.

title: Review: API Security & Authentication
description:
**Area**: Security hardening (authentication, authorization, input validation)

**Review Checklist**:
1. **Authentication & Authorization**:

2. **Input Validation**:

3. **Rate Limiting & DoS Protection**:

4. **Secret Management**:

   - Review database connection string handling

5. **CORS & Headers**:

**Files to Review**:

**Security Review Completed** ✅

## Summary
Comprehensive security audit of authentication, authorization, input validation, rate limiting, secret management, and API security. **No critical vulnerabilities found.**

## Files Reviewed
- internal/auth/jwt.go (JWT implementation)
- internal/auth/apikey.go (API key validation)

- internal/api/middleware/auth_cookie.go (auth middleware)

- internal/validation/url.go (SSRF protection)

## Security Strengths
✅ JWT properly implemented (HS256, expiration, validation)
✅ Bcrypt password hashing (cost 12)
✅ API key validation with constant-time comparison
✅ SQLc prevents SQL injection (no string concatenation)
✅ Excellent rate limiting (multi-tier, login throttling)
✅ Request timeouts configured (10s read, 30s write, 5s header)

**PASS WITH FIXES REQUIRED**

**Recommendation**: Fix P1 issues (server-9hs, server-8ug) before launch. P2 and P3 can be deferred to post-launch if needed.

title: Medium: Function complexity in SyncService.mapJSONLDToEvent
description:
File: internal/domain/federation/sync.go:230-315

Function exceeds complexity limit at 85 lines with high cyclomatic complexity.

Complexity issues:
- Multiple optional field extractions (16+ fields)
- Type assertions for each field
- Default value logic mixed with extraction
- No separation between extraction and mapping

KISS violation: Function does too much (extract + validate + map + default).

Fix: Split into smaller functions:
1. extractRequiredFields(payload) - name, @id, @type
2. extractOptionalFields(payload) - description, url, etc.
3. applyDefaults(params) - license, language, domain
4. mapToDBParams(extracted, defaults) - final assembly

Target: <30 lines per function.

Reference: AGENTS.md code guidelines (functions >50 lines), KISS principle
close_reason: Refactored mapJSONLDToEvent() from 109 lines into 4 focused functions: extractRequiredString (7 lines), createDefaultEventParams (16 lines), extractOptionalEventFields (38 lines), extractOccurrenceData (30 lines). Main function now 25 lines. Improved testability and follows KISS principle. All tests passing.

title: Low: Test helper functions lack error context
description:
Files: tests/integration/federation_sync_auth_test.go, tests/integration/feeds_changes_test.go

Test helper functions (insertFederationNode, postFederationSync, fetchChangeFeed) call require.NoError but lose error context when failing.

Current pattern:
_, err := db.Exec(...)
require.NoError(t, err)

Better pattern:
_, err := db.Exec(...)
require.NoError(t, err, "failed to insert federation node: %v", err)

Impact:
- Test failures harder to debug
- No context about which setup step failed
- Wastes developer time investigating

Fix: Add descriptive messages to all require.NoError calls in test helpers.

Reference: Testing best practices, AGENTS.md test guidelines
close_reason: Added descriptive error messages to 7 require.NoError calls in test helpers (postFederationSync, fetchChangeFeed, updateEventName) for better debugging when tests fail

title: Review: Database Schema & Migration Safety
description:
**Area**: Database layer (PostgreSQL schema, migrations, indexes)

**Review Checklist**:
1. **Schema Design**:
   - Review all tables in internal/storage/postgres/migrations/
   - Verify foreign key constraints, indexes, and triggers
   - Check for missing indexes on frequently queried columns
   - Validate JSONB column usage vs normalized fields
   - Review enum types and check constraints

2. **Migration Safety**:
   - Verify migrations are idempotent and reversible
   - Check for destructive operations (DROP, ALTER with data loss)
   - Validate migration order and dependencies
   - Test rollback scenarios for recent migrations
   - Ensure no data loss paths

3. **Data Integrity**:
   - Review unique constraints (ULIDs, dedup_hash, federation_uri)
   - Check cascade delete behavior
   - Validate timestamp defaults (created_at, updated_at)
   - Review soft delete implementation (deleted_at nullable)
   - Check for orphaned record prevention

4. **Performance**:
   - Review 000007_performance_indexes.up.sql
   - Validate indexes match common query patterns
   - Check for missing indexes on JOIN columns
   - Review JSONB GIN indexes for event_changes.snapshot

**Files to Review**:
- internal/storage/postgres/migrations/*.sql
- docs/togather_schema_design.md
- internal/storage/postgres/queries/*.sql (SQLc queries)

**Deliverables**:
- Document findings in review comment
- Flag any critical schema issues
- Recommend additional indexes if needed
close_reason:
**Database Schema Review Completed** ✅

## Summary
Comprehensive review of PostgreSQL schema, migrations, indexes, data integrity constraints, and performance optimizations. **Schema is well-designed with strong data integrity and performance considerations.**

## Files Reviewed
- **Migrations (11 up, 11 down)**: All migrations have matching rollback scripts
  - 000001_core.up.sql: Core tables (events, places, orgs, occurrences, series)
  - 000002_provenance.up.sql: Source tracking, field provenance
  - 000003_federation.up.sql: Federation nodes, event changes, tombstones
  - 000004_auth.up.sql: Users, API keys
  - 000005_operational.up.sql: Idempotency keys
  - 000007_performance_indexes.up.sql: Optimization indexes
  - 000008-000009: Places/orgs tombstones
  - 000010_changefeed_indexes.up.sql: Change feed performance
  - 000011_tombstone_changefeed.up.sql: Trigger for tombstone→changes
- docs/togather_schema_design.md: Schema documentation

## Schema Strengths
✅ **Data Integrity**: Excellent foreign key constraints, check constraints, unique constraints
✅ **Soft Deletes**: Proper nullable `deleted_at` with partial indexes
✅ **Timestamps**: All tables have `created_at`, `updated_at` with defaults
✅ **Deduplication**: Generated `dedup_hash` column with MD5 hash
✅ **Cascade Behavior**: Proper ON DELETE CASCADE for child tables (occurrences)
✅ **Generated Columns**: `full_address`, `geo_point`, `local_date` (STORED)
✅ **Indexes**: Comprehensive indexing strategy covering:
  - Foreign keys (organizer_id, venue_id, series_id, origin_node_id)
  - Unique constraints (ulid, dedup_hash, federation_uri)
  - Full-text search (GIN indexes with tsvector)
  - Trigram similarity (pg_trgm for fuzzy matching)
  - Geospatial queries (PostGIS GIST indexes)
  - Time-range queries (start_time, end_time composite indexes)
  - Partial indexes for soft deletes, federation sync
✅ **Extensions**: pgcrypto, pg_trgm, postgis properly initialized
✅ **Triggers**: Tombstone→event_changes trigger for federation sync
✅ **Views**: field_conflicts view for provenance resolution
✅ **Check Constraints**: Enum validation, range checks (confidence 0-1, price_min≤price_max)
✅ **Location Validation**: `event_location_required` constraint (venue OR virtual_url)
✅ **Migration Safety**: All migrations are reversible (down scripts present)

## Performance Analysis
✅ Indexes cover common query patterns:
  - Event lookups by ULID: `UNIQUE` index on ulid
  - Deduplication queries: `idx_events_dedup` (WHERE lifecycle_state NOT IN deleted)
  - Federation sync: `idx_events_federation` (origin_node_id, federation_uri)
  - Time-range queries: `idx_occurrences_time_range` (start_time, end_time)
  - Geographic queries: `idx_places_geo` (GIST on geo_point)
  - Full-text search: `idx_events_search_vector`, `idx_places_search` (GIN tsvector)
  - Change feed pagination: `idx_event_changes_sequence` (UNIQUE BIGSERIAL)
✅ Partial indexes reduce size: deleted events, federated events, published events
✅ Composite indexes match JOIN patterns: (event_id, start_time), (venue_id, start_time)
✅ JSONB GIN indexes for snapshot queries

## Issues Found
**NONE** - No schema issues or data integrity problems found.

## Recommendations (Optional Enhancements - Low Priority)
1. **Consider adding index on `users.email`**: Login queries use `GetUserByUsername` but email is also UNIQUE. If email-based login is added, index would help.
2. **Consider composite index on `events(lifecycle_state, published_at)`**: Common query pattern for published events ordered by date.
3. **Monitor `event_changes` table growth**: BIGSERIAL sequence can handle billions of rows, but table may grow large. Consider archival strategy for old changes.
4. **Consider VACUUM/ANALYZE schedule**: For large datasets, regular maintenance improves query planner statistics.

## Deployment Readiness
**PASS** - Schema is production-ready.

The database design demonstrates:
- Strong data modeling principles
- Comprehensive indexing strategy
- Proper data integrity constraints
- Safe migration practices
- Performance optimization
- Federation-first architecture

**No blocking issues found.**

title: High: Federation sync missing occurrence handling
description:
File: internal/domain/federation/sync.go:230-315

The mapJSONLDToEvent function extracts startDate from the payload but doesn't create event_occurrences records. SEL events require at least one occurrence (per FR-059).

Current code validates startDate exists (line 259-264) but only stores it in events.published_at, not in event_occurrences table.

Impact: 
- Federated events violate occurrence_required constraint
- Events cannot be queried by date range
- Breaks SEL compliance

Fix: Extract occurrence data from payload and insert into event_occurrences table using proper repository methods.

Reference: Phase 8 US6 T108, data-model.md occurrence requirements

title: Security: Add request body size limits
description:
**Issue**: Request body size limits not explicitly configured at application level.

**Current State**:
- HTTP server has `MaxHeaderBytes: 1 << 20` (1MB headers)
- No explicit `http.MaxBytesReader` in handlers
- JSON-LD payloads could be arbitrarily large

**Security Impact**:
- Potential DoS via large request bodies
- Memory exhaustion attacks possible
- JSON-LD bomb attacks (deeply nested objects)

**Recommendation**:
1. Add request body size middleware in `internal/api/middleware/request_size.go`
2. Set limits:
   - Public endpoints: 1MB max
   - Federation sync: 10MB max (large event batches)
   - Admin endpoints: 5MB max
3. Use `http.MaxBytesReader` to enforce limits
4. Return `413 Payload Too Large` with proper error message

**Priority**: P2 (DoS mitigation, but rate limiting provides some protection)
close_reason: Request body size limits middleware implemented with comprehensive tests. Limits: 1MB public, 10MB federation, 5MB admin. All 6 tests passing.

title: High: SQL query vulnerable to performance issues with unbounded result sets
description:
File: internal/storage/postgres/queries/feeds.sql:3-22

The ListEventChanges query has WHERE clause that may not be selective enough:
- WHERE sequence_number >  could return millions of rows
- No compound index on (sequence_number, changed_at, action)
- LIMIT applied last after sorting entire result set

Performance issues:
- Large table scans when afterSequence is old
- No index on sequence_number alone
- ORDER BY sequence_number without covering index

Impact:
- Slow queries under load
- Database resource exhaustion
- Timeout failures for federation sync

Fix: 
1. Add index: CREATE INDEX idx_event_changes_feed ON event_changes(sequence_number, changed_at) WHERE action IS NOT NULL;
2. Consider materialized view for hot path
3. Add query timeout hint

Reference: Phase 8 US6 T105, performance best practices
close_reason: Created migration 000010 with compound indexes for change feed performance: 1) idx_event_changes_feed (sequence_number, changed_at) for efficient pagination 2) idx_event_changes_feed_action (action, sequence_number, changed_at) for filtered queries. Both indexes use partial WHERE action IS NOT NULL for efficiency. These indexes will prevent full table scans on large event_changes tables.

- internal/storage/postgres/provenance_repository.go (similar function)

- federation.uuidToString (domain layer)
- provenance_repository.uuidToString (storage layer)

title: Consider Content-Type quality (q) values in Accept header parsing
description:
The current content negotiation in serveWithContentNegotiation() (internal/api/handlers/public_pages.go:174-193) uses simple string matching without respecting quality values (q parameters) in Accept headers. For example: 'Accept: text/html;q=0.8, application/ld+json;q=0.9' should prefer JSON-LD but current code would return HTML.

Impact: Suboptimal content negotiation, doesn't follow HTTP spec (RFC 7231)
Location: internal/api/handlers/public_pages.go:174-193
Suggested fix: Either document this limitation or use a proper Accept header parser that respects q values (e.g., github.com/elnormous/contenttype)
close_reason: Documented content negotiation behavior, limitations (no q-value parsing), and format priority order in godoc. Deferred full RFC 7231 implementation as P4 enhancement.

title: Medium: Missing JSON-LD validation against SHACL shapes
description:
Files: internal/domain/federation/sync.go:164-176

Federation sync validates JSON-LD structure minimally (@context, @id, @type present) but doesn't validate against SEL SHACL shapes.

Current validation:
- Checks for @context existence
- Checks for @id and @type
- Basic required field checks

Missing:
- SHACL shape validation (shapes/event.ttl)
- Schema.org Event compliance
- SEL extension validation
- Property value type checking

Impact:
- Accept malformed events that violate SEL schema
- No early rejection of invalid payloads
- Garbage in = garbage out

Fix: Integrate SHACL validation from tests/contracts/shacl_validation_test.go into sync service.

Reference: Phase 8 US6, T031 SHACL validation requirement, SEL spec compliance
close_reason: Implemented SHACL validation for federation sync endpoint. Uses pyshacl subprocess with fail-open fallback. Validates against shapes/*.ttl before event upsert. Configurable via SHACL_VALIDATION_ENABLED env var. Tests passing.

title: Document database indexes in architecture and schema docs
description:
Update architecture and schema documentation to reflect the new performance indexes added in server-blq.

**Background**:
- Three performance indexes added in migration 000008_performance_indexes
- Currently not documented in architecture or schema design docs
- Operators and developers need to understand index purpose and usage

**New Indexes to Document**:
1. **idx_event_occurrences_event_start**
   - Table: event_occurrences
   - Columns: (event_id, start_time)
   - Purpose: Optimize common joins between events and occurrences
   - Query patterns: Event detail pages with occurrence lists, time-based filtering

2. **idx_events_federation**
   - Table: events
   - Columns: (origin_node_id, federation_uri)
   - Purpose: Optimize federation queries when syncing from remote nodes
   - Query patterns: Change feed queries by origin, federated event lookups

3. **idx_events_deleted**
   - Table: events
   - Columns: (deleted_at) WHERE deleted_at IS NOT NULL
   - Purpose: Partial index for soft delete queries (tombstones)
   - Query patterns: 410 Gone responses, cleanup jobs, federation sync

**Documentation Updates**:

1. **docs/togather_schema_design.md**:
   - Add § 3.5 "Performance Indexes" section after § 3.4
   - List all three indexes with:
     - Index name and definition
     - Purpose and use case
     - Query patterns optimized
     - Performance impact (before/after if measured)
   - Update table of contents

2. **docs/togather_SEL_server_architecture_design_v1.md**:
   - Update § 7.1 "Security Hardening" to mention performance indexes
   - Add note under § 3.2 "Database Strategy":
     - "Strategic indexes optimized for: event occurrence joins, federation queries, soft delete filtering"
   - Reference migration 000008_performance_indexes

3. **internal/storage/postgres/migrations/000008_performance_indexes.up.sql**:
   - Add more detailed comments explaining each index purpose
   - Include example queries that benefit from each index

**Example Documentation Format** (for schema doc):



**Success Criteria**:
- All three indexes documented in schema design
- Architecture doc references performance optimization work
- Migration file has clear inline comments
- Developers understand when to use (or avoid) these indexes

**References**:
- Migration: internal/storage/postgres/migrations/000008_performance_indexes.up.sql
- Original issue: server-blq (P2 security fix)
- CODE_REVIEW.md issue #9
close_reason: Documented all 3 performance indexes in migration comments, schema design (new § 3.5), and architecture doc. Includes query patterns and examples.

title: Complete test coverage to 80%+ for domain/events package
description:
Continue test coverage improvements started in server-3t3. Current: 43.1%, Target: 80%+. Focus areas:
  
**Untested Functions (0% coverage)**:
- BuildDedupHash (dedup.go)
- IngestService methods (ingest.go)
- Helper functions in ingest.go (createOccurrences, recordSource, etc.)

**Test Scenarios Needed**:
- Ingestion edge cases (duplicate events, invalid data, large payloads)
- Deduplication logic with hash collisions
- Concurrency scenarios (multiple agents submitting similar events)
- Error handling paths in validation and normalization
- Boundary conditions (max lengths, null values, empty arrays)

**Implementation**:
- Create ingest_test.go with table-driven tests
- Create dedup_test.go for hash generation tests
- Add integration tests in tests/integration/ for full ingestion flow
- Use test fixtures for complex event inputs

**Success Criteria**:
- domain/events package reaches 80%+ coverage
- All critical business logic paths tested
- Edge cases and error conditions covered

See CODE_REVIEW.md issue #18 for original requirements.
notes: Significant progress: 43.1% → 60.3% (+17.2pp). All helper functions and utilities now tested. Remaining work requires repository mocking for integration tests (Ingest methods, createOccurrences, recordSource). Created comprehensive unit tests with edge cases, normalization, determinism, and boundary conditions.
close_reason: Test coverage increased from 43.1% to 83.4% (+40.3pp), exceeding 80% goal. Created comprehensive test suite with MockRepository for ingestion flows, service methods, and validation functions. All tests passing.
